waspy: Relating to or typical of a WASP (= White Anglo-Saxon Protestant)
waste: An unnecessary or wrong use of money, substances, time, energy, abilities, etc.
watch: To look at something for a period of time, especially something that is changing or moving
water: A clear liquid, without colour or taste, that falls from the sky as rain and is necessary for animal and plant life
waver: To lose strength, determination, or purpose, especially temporarily
waxen: A waxen face has pale, shiny skin and does not look healthy
wazoo: A person's bottom (= the part of the body you sit on) or anus (= the opening through which solid waste leaves the body)
weary: Very tired, especially after working hard for a long time
weave: To make cloth by repeatedly crossing a single thread through two sets of long threads on a loom (= special frame)
wedge: A piece of metal, wood, rubber, etc. with a pointed edge at one end and a wide edge at the other, either pushed between two objects to keep them still or forced into something to break pieces off it
weigh: To have a heaviness of a stated amount, or to measure the heaviness of an object
weird: Very strange and unusual, unexpected, or not natural
welch: To avoid doing something you have promised to do, especially not to pay a debt
welsh: Belonging to or relating to Wales, its people, or its language
wetly: In a way that involves water or another liquid
whack: To hit someone or something noisily
whale: A very large sea mammal that breathes air through a hole at the top of its head
whang: To hit or throw something using force
wharf: An area like a wide wall built near the edge of the sea or a river where ships can be tied and goods can be taken off them
wheat: A plant whose yellowish-brown grain is used for making flour, or the grain itself
wheel: A circular object connected at the centre to a bar, used for making vehicles or parts of machines move
whelk: A soft sea creature, similar to a snail, that lives in a hard shell
where: To, at, or in what place
which: (used in questions and structures in which there is a fixed or limited set of answers or possibilities) what one or ones
whiff: A slight smell, carried on a current of air
while: During the time that, or at the same time as
whine: To make a long, high, sad sound
whiny: Complaining a lot in an annoying way, especially in a high, sad voice
whirl: To (cause something to) turn around in circles
whirr: (especially of machines) to make a low, soft, continuous sound
whisk: To take something or someone somewhere else suddenly and quickly
whist: A card game played between two pairs of players in which each side tries to win more cards than the other
white: Of a colour like that of snow, milk, or bone
whizz: To move or do something very fast
whoop: To give a loud, excited shout, especially to show your enjoyment of or agreement with something
whorl: A circular pattern of lines, with the smallest circle in the middle, surrounded by other circles, each one wider and larger than the previous one
whose: Used especially in questions when asking about which person owns or is responsible for something
widen: To become, or to make something greater in width
widow: A woman whose husband or wife has died and who has not married again
width: The distance across something from one side to the other
wield: To hold a weapon or tool and look as if you are going to use it
wight: A ghost, or a dead person who has come back to life
wilco: Especially in communication by radio, used to say that you agree to do what is asked
wince: To show pain or embarrassment suddenly and for a short time in the face, often moving the head back at the same time
winch: A machine that lifts heavy objects by turning a chain or rope around a tube-shaped device
wisha: An expression used to show surprise or to emphasize something
wispy: In the form of a wisp or wisps
witch: A woman who is believed to have magical powers and who uses them to harm or help other people
witty: Using words in a clever and funny way
wodge: A thick piece or a large amount of something
woody: Like wood, for example in taste or smell
woozy: Feeling weak or ill and unable to think clearly
world: The earth and all the people, places, and things on it
wormy: Containing worms, or infected or damaged by worms
worry: To think about problems or unpleasant things that might happen in a way that makes you feel unhappy and frightened
worst: Superlative of bad : of the lowest quality, or the most unpleasant, difficult, or severe
worth: Having a particular value, especially in money
would: Used to refer to future time from the point of view of the past
wound: A damaged area of the body, such as a cut or hole in the skin or flesh made by a weapon
wrack: A frame or shelf, often formed of bars, that is used to hold things
wreak: To cause something to happen in a violent and often uncontrolled way
wreck: To destroy or badly damage something
wrest: To get something with effort or difficulty
wring: To hold something tightly with both hands and twist it by turning your hands in opposite directions
wrist: The part of the body between the hand and the arm
write: To make marks that represent letters, words, or numbers on a surface, such as paper or a computer screen, using a pen, pencil, or keyboard, or to use this method to record thoughts, facts, or messages
wrung: To hold something tightly with both hands and twist it by turning your hands in opposite directions
wryly: In a way that shows you find a bad or difficult situation slightly funny
xanax: A brand name for a drug used to treat anxiety
xenon: A chemical element that is a gas with no colour or smell. Xenon does not react with other elements and is used in some types of light bulb.
xerox: A brand name for a copy of a document or other piece of paper with writing or printing on it, made by a machine that uses a photographic process, or the machine or process itself
yacht: A boat with sails and sometimes an engine, used for either racing or travelling on for pleasure
yahoo: A rude, loud, unpleasant person, especially one who has little education
yappy: (of a dog) often making short high sounds
yearn: To wish very strongly, especially for something that you cannot have or something that is very difficult to have
yeast: A type of fungus that is used in making alcoholic drinks such as beer and wine, and for making bread swell and become light
yield: To supply or produce something positive such as a profit, an amount of food or information
yodel: To sing by making a series of very fast changes between the natural voice and a much higher voice
yogic: Relating to the activity or philosophy of yoga
yokel: A stupid or awkward person who lives in the countryside rather than a town, especially one whose appearance is in some way strange or humorous
young: Having lived or existed for only a short time and not old
youth: The period of your life when you are young, or the state of being young
yucca: A plant with long, stiff leaves on a thick stem and sometimes white, bell-shaped flowers
yukon: A territory (= a large area of a country that has some local government but less independence than a province or a state) of northwestern Canada, whose capital city is Whitehorse
zaire: A former name for the the Democratic Republic of the Congo
zebra: An African wild animal that looks like a horse, with black or brown and white lines on its body
zelig: A person who appears in many different situations and who changes their behaviour or appearance to suit the situation that they are in at the time
zhuzh: To make something more interesting or attractive by changing it slightly or adding something to it
zloty: The standard unit of money used in Poland
zonal: Relating to or arranged in zones
zumba: A brand name for a type of exercise in which you do dance moves and other exercises to Latin American music, usually in a class with other people
